explanation: Most final consonants are silent, especially S, T, D, X, P, Z. Remember CaReFuL: final C, R, F, L are usually pronounced.
Final C, R, F, L (and sometimes B, K, Q) are pronounced at the end of words.
Vowels followed by M or N (in the same syllable) are nasalized: air flows through nose and mouth. The M/N is silent.
AN, EN, EM at end or before consonant → nasal [ɑ̃] sound.
ON, OM → nasal [ɔ̃] sound.
IN, IM, AIN, AIM, EIN → nasal [ɛ̃] sound.
UN, UM → nasal [œ̃] (rounded) sound.
The French R is guttural/uvular [ʁ], produced in the throat (like gargling).
U is a front rounded vowel: purse lips like 'oo' but say 'ee'.
OU is back rounded like English 'oo' in food.
É (acute accent) is closed [e], like 'ay' in 'day' but shorter.
È or Ê (grave or circumflex) is open [ɛ], like 'e' in 'bet'.
Unaccented E in middle often [ə] (schwa) or drops entirely; final E usually silent.
CH is 'sh' like English 'ship'.
GN is like 'ny' in 'canyon'.
S between vowels is voiced [z]; otherwise [s]. Final S silent (plural).
Required after determiners (les, des, mon), pronouns (ils, vous), short adjectives.
Possible in many cases; common in careful speech but often dropped casually.
Never after 'et' (and), singular nouns, or aspirated H.
OI is [wa] like 'wa' in 'watt'.
EU/ŒU closed [ø] (like German 'ö'); open [œ] before R or consonant.
AI/EI usually [ɛ] like open E.
AU/EAU is closed [o] like 'oh'.
ENT at end of 3rd person plural verbs is silent.
French has even syllable stress (no strong accent); rhythm is syllable-timed.
